how do we get ourselves to do the things

this catchy little phrase sounds rather

PS the first lesson is that if we
physically prepare for something it will
make it significantly easier to go ahead
and do it let me explain so let's say

some days we wake up feeling tired and

the six piece come in we can physically
prepare beforehand by wearing our gym
clothes to bed why would we want to do
this well studies have found that it
actually requires more willpower and
mental energy to put on your gym clothes
and walk out the front door to go to the
gym then the actual workout that takes
place at the gym and this is because
putting on your gym clothes requires you
to make a decision should I go to the
gym today it's this decision that gives
us the hardest time right we never have
an issue lifting weights at the gym when
we're already there we basically do that
automatically the issue has always been
convincing our lazy ass to get out of
bed to put on our gym clothes and to go
to the gym if we wear our gym clothes to
bed we're basically making the decision
to go to the gym the night before so we
don't have to spend nearly as much
mental energy in the morning which makes
going to the gym much easier prior
planning prevents piss-poor performance

a brain is kind of like a horse if
there's no one riding the horse if you
don't give it any directions it will
just roam around doing whatever it wants
you've probably noticed this before in
your own life if you have no plans for
the following day you most likely just
bum around on autopilot doing whatever
now this brings up the question of well
how exactly should we give our horse
directions how should we lay out and
plan ahead well there are tons of
different ways to do so but I'll share
with you what I find to be the most
effective as some of you guys already
know I use white boards to organize a
large part of my life one of these
boards is what I like to call the to do
board basically what I plan on doing the
next day and I almost always finish
everything on this board mainly because
I stick to a couple of fundamental rules
the first rule is that I only put a
maximum of three things on the board
sometimes I even do just one or two
things if I can complete whatever is on
the board
that means I've accomplished all the
work I need to do and I can relax if I
want to do more work that's up to me and
often times I do but the reason I put so
few things on the board
is because I want to make completing the
board into a habit if you have too many
tasks you're gonna find it very hard to
complete the entire board every single
day maybe you'll do so for a week but
chances are your streak won't last very
long by lowering your standards and only
putting a few things on the board you
can develop this habit much easier and
once the habit is locked in it starts to
feel extremely uncomfortable when you
think about not completing the board and
you can use that feeling to your
advantage
the second rule I have is to use
chunking which is essentially breaking
big tasks down into tiny parts for
example I won't put something like
finished video for next Saturday on the
whiteboard because it would take me
around ten hours of non-stop work just
to be able to pull this off when you
present your brain of such a big
challenge it's not gonna want to do it
it seems way too hard so you
procrastinate and you'll say hey we'll
just do this later instead I'll put
something like write the rough draft
which is something that I know I can get
done in about an hour this is a much
less challenging foe in the eyes of my
brain and because of this it sees no
reason to push it aside because it knows
we can easily get this done right then
and there so remember guys if you're
having issues or procrastination prior
planning prevents piss-poor performance
the six piece teaches us that we should
